This is the pre-litigation stage where the plaintiff and the plaintiff's legal team discuss the case facts, evidence, and legal basis, and jointly strategize on the case.;The information you need to know is as follows:

            The summary of the previous dialogue history is:<summary>
The plaintiff claims to have an oral agreement with the defendant's company for a monthly salary and unpaid wages, and has provided evidence such as ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony. It is important to investigate the company's policies and regulations regarding part-time employees to determine the validity of the plaintiff's claims.
.</summary>            The latest conversation record is as follows:
<hisroty> Mike said that :As the plaintiff, you can defend your rights and interests in court by presenting the evidence you have, such as the ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony, to support your claim for unpaid wages and breach of contract. Your legal strategy should focus on proving the existence of the oral agreement and demonstrating that the defendant's company failed to fulfill its obligations.Alex said that :To defend your rights and interests in court, you can rely on the evidence you have, such as the ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony, to establish the existence of the oral agreement and the defendant's failure to fulfill their obligations. Additionally, you can argue that the defendant's company's policies and regulations regarding part-time employees should not negate the agreed-upon payment terms.Aaron said that :To defend your rights and interests in court, it is crucial to emphasize the enforceability of oral agreements and the defendant's failure to fulfill their obligations. Present the evidence, such as the ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony, to establish the existence of the agreement and the defendant's breach of contract. Argue that the defendant's company policies should not override the agreed-upon payment terms.Alice said that :To defend your rights and interests in court, it is important to emphasize the enforceability of oral agreements and the defendant's failure to fulfill their obligations. Present the evidence, such as the ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony, to establish the existence of the agreement and the defendant's breach of contract. Argue that the defendant's company policies should not override the agreed-upon payment terms. Additionally, consider seeking legal advice to develop a strong legal strategy.
</history>,            the relevant chat history you may need is:<relevant>Aaron said that :To defend your rights and interests in court, it is crucial to emphasize the enforceability of oral agreements and the defendant's failure to fulfill their obligations. message.content: The plaintiff should focus on presenting evidence such as ID card, promotional sales records, work sign-in sheets, and witness testimony to prove the existence of the oral agreement and the defendant's failure to fulfill their obligations. They should also argue that the defendant's company policies should not override the agreed-upon payment terms. Seeking legal advice to develop a strong legal strategy is recommended.
